q3.value:
Full publication details of Qiu and Johns (2019): Qiu, M. and Johns, B.T. Semantic diversity in paired-associate learning: Further evidence for the information accumulation perspective of cognitive aging. Psychon Bull Rev 27, 114–121 (2020). https://doi.org/10.3758/s13423-019-01691-w 

In Qiu and Johns (2019), young and old adults first memorized 10 word pairs (e.g., wolf-beach). Immediately afterwards, the participants recalled what word previously paired with e.g., wolf in a cued recall task. Here, "wolf" is the cue word. All participants remembered a total of 40 word pairs.

Qiu & Johns (2019) reported that a cue word's semantic diversity has no effect on the accuracy rate in the cued recall task.

In the current replication, I test whether the total degree of a cue word, derived from the semantic associate norm by De Deyne, Navarro, Perfors, Brysbaert, and Storms, (2019), influences the ease with which a correct response is given.

q4.value: It is hypothesized that words with a higher total degree are better at forming association with other words. Therefore, it is predicted that accuracy in recall is better in trials where the cue words have a higher total degree.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: All the experimental procedures are identical to Qiu & Johns (2019). For details, please refer to their article.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from Prolific (www.prolific.co). Eligibility criteria: aged between 18 and 29, no history of learning/language impairment, university-educated (or in the process of it), and speak English as their first language. Exclusionary criteria: Participants whose accuracy rate in the cued recall task is 2.5 standard deviations below the sample mean will be excluded OR participants who failed to achieve over 70% accuracy in the attention check will be excluded.

q13.value: The target sample size is 52 participants. This is because Qiu and Johns (2019) had 52 participants. I will attempt to recruit up to 60, assuming that not all will be able to complete the task.

question.value:
There are two independent variables in the cued recall task: (1) total degree (of cue word) in semantic network and (2) Log Frequency (of cue word). Both are numerical variables. Total degrees in semantic network is calculated using the free association norm by De Deyne, Navarro, Perfors, Brysbaert, and Storms, (2019). In this norm, each cue word elicited three responses, but in the degree calculation here, only the first response will be used. The total degree of a word is the sum of its (a) out-degree and (b) in-degree. Out-degree refers to the number of distinct responses a cue word elicits. For example, if "dog" elicits "cat", "bark", and "pet", the word "dog" will therefore have an out-degree of 3. In-degree, on the other hand, refers to how many times a word has been given as a response. For example, if "cat" elicits "dog", and "animal" also elicits "dog", the word "dog" will have an in-degree of 2. In this example, the word "dog" will have a total degree of 3 plus 2 (i.e., 5) Note, in the calculation of both in- and out-degrees, I follow Nelson et al. (2004) in that a response is only considered "valid" if at least two persons in the norming study gave it as the response. For example, if only one participant in De Deyne et al.'s (2019) study gave "stupid" as an associate to "Einstein", "stupid" will NOT be considered as a "valid" associate. But if two or more persons gave "stupid" as a response, it will be considered as a "valid" associate (and hence in the degree calculation). A spreadsheet containing all the in- and out-degrees of all the words sampled in De Deyne et al. (2019) is available in the project repository. Name of file: de_deyne(2019)_all_with_degree.csv

For log frequency, I used the data from the English Lexicon Project (Balota et al., 2007).
Dependent variable in cued recall task: Correct or Incorrect (i.e., binary).

Generalized linear mixed effect model will be used to analyze the accuracy data. Dependent variable is binary: Correct or Incorrect. Total degree, log frequency, and their interaction will be entered as fixed factors. Analysis script is attached. Following Barr et al. (2013), all the models will be first computed with a maximal random structure. If a model fails to converge or achieve a non-singular fit, the random-effect structure will be simplified (e.g., Barr et al., 2013; Bolker et al., 2009). If the maximal model or the more maximal converged, their explanatory values will be compared with the random-intercept-only model, using anova model comparison. If the two models do not differ (as indexed by a threshold of chisq smaller than 3; Jaeger, 2011), the random-intercept-only model is favoured as this is considered more statistically powerful (Matuschek et al., 2017). However, if the two models differ (chisq larger than 3), the conservative model a more maximal structure will be reported.

q20.value: The scale() function in R will be used for all the numerical fixed factors entered into the GLME models.

q21.value: Results are considered statistically significant if p-value is smaller than 0.05.

q22.value: Exclusionary criteria: Participants whose accuracy rate in the cued recall task is 2.5 standard deviations below the sample mean will be excluded OR participants who failed to achieve over 70% accuracy in the attention check will be excluded.

q23.value: If data from a participant are excluded for the above reasons, a new participant will be recruited as replacement.

q24.value: The effect of semantic diversity, orthographic neighbour, semantic neighbour, age of acquisition, and concreteness/imageability will be explored.

attributes.title: Question Framing and Moral Judgment in Sacrificial Dilemmas

summary.value: The SPSS file contains the data used in this study.  It's "merged" in the sense that it includes the data from from both scale orders: right above wrong (RW, coded as 1) and wrong above right (WR, coded as 2).  The two HTML files are copies of all pages of the survey as shown to the researcher on SurveyMonkey.  All participants initially accessed a version that had an Informed Consent Statement followed by a sorting page that randomly assigned half of participants to receive the RW condition, which was administered on the same survey, and half of participants to the WR condition, which was accomplished by switching them to an alternate version of the survey.  This is the file labeled "Reverse Scale Order".

q1.value: Empathy effects of physical and emotional interpretations of others' pain

q3.value: In this project, we explore whether perceptions of others' pain is influenced by whether pain is interpreted as physical or emotional. We will attempt to replicate and confirm the results of three prior studies using a set of more tightly controlled stimuli. We will also test several exploratory hypotheses generated from prior studies.

q4.value:
Primary hypotheses: 

We have the following confirmatory hypotheses, which we confirmed in two prior studies.

1. People will view another's pain as more painful if they focus on how the person feels emotionally (vs. physically)

2.  People will view another's pain as persisting more over time if they focus on how the person feels emotionally (vs. physically)

3.  People will view another's pain as more distressing to read about if they focus on how the person feels emotionally (vs. physically)

These hypotheses were supported in two prior studies and we will look to replicate them in this study.

Secondary hypotheses:

In addition, we predict the following, which is based on an exploratory result of two prior studies:

1. People will rate pain as more controllable if they focus on emotional pain rather than physical pain 

Exploratory Hypotheses:

Finally, we have the following exploratory hypotheses, which we found in one prior study but did not replicate in a follow-up:

1. Willingness to help physical vs. emotional pain will be moderated by trait empathy (measured with trait empathic concern and perspective-taking; Davis, 1980), such that people who are high in trait empathy will be more willing to help another person if they focus on how that person feels emotionally (vs. physically), while people low in trait empathy will be more willing to help another person if they focus on how that person feels physically (vs. emotionally). Because trait empathy will be measured using both empathic concern and perspective-taking, we will test this hypothesis twice: once with empathic concern as a moderator and once with perspective-taking as a moderator. 

2. Capability of helping physical vs. emotional pain will be moderated by trait empathy, such that people who are high in trait empathy will feel more capable of helping another person if they focus on how that person feels emotionally (vs. physically), while people low in trait empathy will feel more capable of helping another person if they focus on how that person feels physically (vs. emotionally). We will also test this hypothesis twice: once with empathic concern as a moderator and once with perspective-taking as a moderator.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study will follow a fully within subjects design with two conditions: physical and emotional. Participants will read four vignettes in each condition. The vignettes in the physical condition and in the emotional condition will be identical, but will have different instructions: In the physical condition, participants will be instructed to focus on how the person in the vignette feels physically; in the emotional condition, they will be instructed to focus on how the person feels emotionally. Thus, participants will read a total of eight vignettes (four per condition).

q9.value: Participants will also be randomly assigned to read either 1. Version A of vignettes 1 and 2 and Version B of vignettes 3 and 4; or 2. Version B of vignettes 1 and 2 and Version A of vignettes 3 and 4. Each version of these vignettes can be located in the "Emotional and Physical Pain Vignettes" file attached.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will use TurkPrime (Litman, Robinson, & Abberbock, 2017) to recruit participants from Amazon Mechanical Turk, who will each be compensated $1. Participants will be English-speaking and over the age of 18. In addition, to ensure data quality we will only collect data from participants who have completed 1000 HITs and who have a 95% HIT approval. Using exclusion features available on TurkPrime, participants will be automatically prevented from completing the study if they have already completed the study once, if their worker ID matches a worker ID from a previous study in this project, if they are flagged with a suspicious geolocation.

q13.value: We will collect data from 200 participants.

q14.value: Based on a power analysis, this sample size will give us 99% power to detect a medium effect size between two dependent groups, and 80% power to detect a small effect.

question.value: We will manipulate pain type as our independent variable. There will be two levels: emotional and physical.

Participants will complete each outcome measure after reading each vignette. Thus, each participant will respond to reach outcome measure a total of four times per condition.

Our primary dependent variables will be the following, each tapping into the participants' empathic response to the target's pain: pain (how much pain the participant believes the target in the vignette is experiencing), persistence (how much time the participant believes the target's pain will persist), and distress (how distressing it was for the participant to read about the target's pain). 

As secondary/ancillary measures, we will also measure control (how much control the target has over his pain), understanding (how easy it was to understand the target's pain), and help need (how much help the target needs). 

To test our exploratory hypotheses, we will measure willingness to help (how willing the participant would be to help the target), capability of helping (how capable the participant feels they would be of helping the target), and the empathic concern and perspective-taking sub-scales of the Interpersonal Reactivity Index (Davis, 1980). 

Participants will also complete the personal distress and fantasy subscales of the Interpersonal Reactivity Index, as well as the Empathy Index (Jordan, Amir, & Bloom, 2016), which we will use for exploratory analyses. 

For each outcome measure, participants will respond on a 1(not at all) to 7 (very much) Likert scale. For the Interpersonal Reactivity Index and the Empathy Index, participants will respond on a 1 (does not describe me well) to 5 (describes me very well) Likert scale. Each measure we will use in this study can be found in the "Emotional and Physical Pain Measures" document located in this preregistration.

data.name: Emotional and Physical Pain Measures Preregistration.docx

extra.selectedFileName: Emotional and Physical Pain Measures Preregistration.docx

question.value:
For each of our outcomes variable, we will take the average response across all four vignettes within each condition.  Other than this averaging, we will not index any of the outcome variables.

For the Interpersonal Reactivity Index and the Empathy Index, we will take the average of the 7 items within each sub-scale to index empathic concern, perspective-taking, personal distress, fantasy, emotion contagion, and behavioral contagion.
For each of our outcome variables, we will conduct dependent samples t-tests to test for differences between the emotional and physical pain conditions on these averages.

q21.value: We will use a cut-off value of p < .05 (two-tailed tests) as our threshold for statistical significance.

q22.value: Participants will be excluded if they do not complete any of the outcome variables. We will not include awareness or attention checks in this study. Because each response will be completed on either on a 1-5 or 1-7 Likert scale, it is unlikely that there will be any outliers unless a variable has an extremely non-normal distribution.

q23.value: A participant will not be included in the analysis if they do not complete each of the outcome variables.

q24.value: To test for our exploratory interaction hypotheses, we will conduct a linear regression in which responses on the empathic concern and perspective-taking scales predict the difference score between the physical and emotional conditions. We will run this model with willingness to help as the dependent variable and again with capability of helping as the dependent variable. If the interaction is significant, we will conduct simple effects tests.

q25.value:
We cited the following literature in this preregistration:

Davis, M. H. (1983). Measuring individual differences in empathy: Evidence for a multidimensional approach. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 44, 113–126. 

Jordan, M. R., Amir, D., & Bloom, P. (2016). Are empathy and concern psychologically distinct? Emotion, 16(8), 1107.

Litman, L., Robinson, J., & Abberbock, T. (2017). TurkPrime. com: A versatile crowdsourcing data acquisition platform for the behavioral sciences. Behavior Research Methods, 49(2), 433-442.

attributes.title: Mindfulness, 3D Multiple Object Tracking and Socio-Emotional Function

q1.value: Mindfulness, 3D-Multiple Object Tracking, and Socio-emotional Functioning

q2.value: Tyler Meadows, Rob McCaffrey, Erin Harris, Laura Pollice, Kim D. Dorsch

q3.value:
Mindfulness is described as attention and awareness in the present moment, while experiencing the present moment with an open and non-judgemental attitude (Kabatt-Zin, 1994; Lindsay & Creswell, 2017). Monitor and acceptance theory (MAT) is a new framework to test and make predictions regarding the outcomes of mindfulness (Lindsay & Creswell, 2017) Acceptance, combined with attention monitoring has been shown to enhance cognition when affect is present, in addition to improving stress related health outcomes, and reducing negative reactivity (e.g., depression, anxiety, stress) (Lindsay & Creswell, 2017).  This project is seeking to understand the relationships among dispositional mindfulness, divided attention, dispositional resilience (i.e., hardiness), psychological well-being, self-compassion, mindset, and perceived stress.  The Philadelphia Mindfulness Scale (PHLMS) is a valid and reliable measure that examines mindfulness on 2 dimensions awareness and acceptance. This 20-item scale uses a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (never) to 5 (very often)
(Cardaciotto, Herbert, Forman, Moitra, & Farrow, 2008).

Divided attention (i.e., 3-D multiple object tracking) refers to the ability to monitor and track multiple objects for short periods of time (Parsons et al., 2014) and will be measured using the NeuroTracker (Cognisens). The NeuroTracker task consists of following 4 of 8 target objects in a 3-dimensional space for 20 trials of 8 second duration (3 times).  After 8 seconds the participant is asked to identify the targets and if correct, the speed of the objects increases for the next trial.  If incorrect, the speed of the objects in the next trial decreases. The dependent measure is the averaged visual tracking speed over 60 trials.

Dispositional resilience (i.e., hardiness) refers to one's ability to interpret stressful events using a general framework of a strong sense of life and work commitment, a greater feeling of control over life events, and an openness to change and challenge (Kobasa, 1979). The Dispositional Resilience Scale (Bartone, 2014) will be used to measure this construct.

While there are a number of ways to define psychological well-being, the PERMA model advocated by Seligman (2011) will be used in this study.  Based in a framework of positive psychology, Seligman suggests there are five pillars to psychological well-being:  positive emotions, engagement, relationships, meaning, and accomplishment.  The PERMA-Profiler (Butler & Kern, 2016) will be used to measure this construct.

Self-compassion refers to the tendency to be open to one's experiences of suffering and to respond with self-kindness, taking an understanding and nonjudgmental attitude toward the failure, and believing that the experience is a common human experience (Neff, 2003).  The Self-Compassion Scale (Neff, 2003) will be used to measure this construct.

Dweck (2006) identified two ways in which individuals can view their abilities.  An individual with a fixed mindset views abilities as innate qualities; there is no changing what you are born with.  Whereas individuals with a growth mindset believe that abilties can be learned and acquired through effort and experience.  We will measure participants' mindset towards attentional training using Dweck's (2006) fixed/growth mindset questionnaire.

Personal relative deprivation is a subjective measurement of feelings of anger and resentment based on an immediate social comparison to one's peer group (Smith, Pettigrew, Peppen, & Bialosiewicz, 2012). Relative deprivation has been shown to influence a number of psychological outcomes at the individual level, including problem gambling, mental health, and physical health (Callan et al., 2008; Callan, Shead, & Olson, 2011; Mishra & Carleton, 2015).

Most of the constructs discussed so far, with the exception of divided attention, have been clearly shown to be related to the experience of stress.  Consequently, the Perceived Stress Scale (Cohen, Kamarck, & Mermelstein, 1983) will be included to objectively measure feelings of perceived stress over the past month.

Throughout all the constructs outlined above, there is some debate as to whether they are dispositional (i.e., trait-like personality characteristics) or are factors that can be learned and acquired through interventions.  It is the ultimate purpose of this project to ascertain the relationships among these psychological constructs as a first step to determine the existence and extent of those relationships.

q4.value:
1. The primary hypothesis that we are investigating for this study is whether there is a relationship between NeuroTracker (NT; 3DMOT) speed scores and dispositional mindfulness as measured by the PHLMS. We predict that there will be a positive relationship between awareness scores and NT scores.
2. Secondly, we predict that awareness and acceptance scores will positively correlate with PERMA scores, dispositional Hardiness scores, self-compassion scores and a growth mindset. 
3. Thirdly, we predict that awareness and acceptance skills will be negatively associated with perceived stress scores and relative deprivation scores. 
4. Personal relative deprivation scores will predict both perceived stress and PERMA scores, while awareness and acceptance scores we predict will moderate this relationship. 
5. Lastly, there will be multiple exploratory analyses conducted to assess the relationships between the variables outlined.

question.value:
In this cross-sectional correlation design, participants must be at least 18 years of age, proficient in the English Language,  have normal or corrected to normal vision, and have no history of epilepsy, seizures, or colour vision deficiency for safety reasons. Participants must also not have experience with the NeuroTracker task.  Participants will be recruited from the Psychology Participant pool, the Kinesiology student body, and the general community via posters and email recruiting.

Participants will be asked to come to the Motivation for Active Living Laboratory (KHS 157) where a researcher will go through an online consent form with the participant ensuring they understand their rights as participants and consent to the research. They will be provided with a hard copy of the consent form for their records.  Participants will complete 1 practice block of the NeuroTracker to get used to the task and ensure everyone has the same level of understanding. After completing three further blocks (60 trials) of the NeuroTracker, participants will then complete a 20-25 minute questionnaire consisting of the scales mentioned in the section above and demographic questions (survey data collected through the Qualtrics platform). They will be completing the questionnaire subsequent to the NeuroTracker task to eliminate any framing biases in focusing their attention more during the task.  Once completed, participants will be taken through a debriefing form online with a researcher. 

It is anticipated that the total time commitment will be approximately 60 minutes.  Participants will be thanked and will receive 1% credit via the participant pool if recruited through the Psychology Participant Pool.

Mindfulness is described as attention and awareness in the present moment, while experiencing the present moment with an open and non-judgemental attitude. The Philadelphia Mindfulness Scale (PHLMS) is a valid and reliable measure that examines mindfulness on 2 dimensions awareness and acceptance. This 20-item scale uses a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (never) to 5 (very often)
(Cardaciotto, Herbert, Forman, Moitra, & Farrow, 2008).

Divided attention (i.e., 3-D multiple object tracking) refers to the ability to monitor and track multiple objects for short periods of time (Parsons et al., 2014) and will be measured using the NeuroTracker (Cognisens). The NeuroTracker task consists of following 4 of 8 target objects in a 3-dimensional space for 20 trials of 8 second duration (3 times).  After 8 seconds the participant is asked to identify the targets and if correct, the speed of the objects increases for the next trial.  If incorrect, the speed of the objects in the next trial decreases. The dependent measure is the averaged visual tracking speed over 60 trials.

Dispositional resilience (i.e., hardiness) refers to one's ability to interpret stressful events using a general framework of a strong sense of life and work commitment, a greater feeling of control over life events, and an openness to change and challenge (Kobasa, 1979). The Dispositional Resilience Scale (Bartone, 2014) will be used to measure this construct.

While there are a number of ways to define psychological well-being, the PERMA model advocated by Seligman (2011) will be used in this study.  Based in a framework of positive psychology, Seligman suggests there are five pillars to psychological well-being:  positive emotions, engagement, relationships, meaning, and accomplishment.  The PERMA-Profiler (Butler & Kern, 2016) will be used to measure this construct.

Self-compassion refers to the tendency to be open to one's experiences of suffering and to respond with self-kindness, taking an understanding and nonjudgmental attitude toward the failure, and believing that the experience is a common human experience (Neff, 2003).  The Self-Compassion Scale (Neff, 2003) will be used to measure this construct.

Dweck (2006) identified two ways in which individuals can view their abilities.  An individual with a fixed mindset views abilities as innate qualities; there is no changing what you are born with.  Whereas individuals with a growth mindset believe that abilties can be learned and acquired through effort and experience.  We will measure participants' mindset towards attentional training using Dweck's (2006) fixed/growth mindset questionnaire.

Personal relative deprivation is a subjective measurement of feelings of anger and resentment based on an immediate social comparison to one's peer group (Smith, Pettigrew, Peppen, & Bialosiewicz, 2012). Relative deprivation has been shown to influence a number of psychological outcomes at the individual level, including problem gambling, mental health, and physical health (Callan et al., 2008; Callan, Shead, & Olson, 2011; Mishra & Carleton, 2015).

Measures do have suggested analysis regarding mean scores and aggregating, those guidelines will be followed for each measure. Any missing data less than 20% of the total items will be corrected using the series mean. (i.e. 9/10 questions answered; 1 missing data point will be inputed using the series mean)

There are two attention checks in the study, if participants do not pass the attention checks they will be excluded from analyses. Further, if a participant does not complete at least 80% of the measure then they will be excluded from analyses. 

Correlational analysis will be conducted on all variables (mindfulness, hardiness, mindset, self-compassion, NT score, wellbeing, perceived stress, and personal relative deprivation).

Multiple regressions will be conducted. It is expected that regressions will include demographic variables as covariates, and mindfulness, hardiness, self-compassion, personal relative deprivation, perceived stress and mindset as predictors of wellbeing. 

Exploratory multiple regressions will be conducted on mindfulness (awareness and acceptance) and NT scores. We are exploring if dispositional mindfulness predicts NT scores or if NT scores predict dispositional mindfulness. 

Hayes Process mediation and moderation will be conducted on relative deprivation, mindfulness and perceived stress and wellbeing. Wherein relative deprivation is the predictor variable, PS and wellbeing are the dependent variables and mindfulness (awareness and acceptance) is the moderator variable. 

Further Mindset will be used as a predictor variable in a regression for NT scores. We expect a growth mindset to predict higher NT scores rather than a fixed mindset.

attributes.title: Language and Literacy Problems among Children with Social-Emotional-Behavioral Concerns

q1.value: Language and Literacy Problems among Children with Emotional-Behavioral Concerns

q2.value: Karla Kay McGregor, Erin Smolak, Jacob Oleson

q3.value:
The overall goal of the project is to determine the prevalence of language/literacy disorder among children with emotional-behavioral problems at Boys Town and to examine the association between their language profiles and their emotional-behavioral health.

Extant evidence suggests there is comorbidity of language/literacy disorders and emotional-behavioral (EB) concerns in children, adolescents, and adults. However, we know little about the nature of these language problems nor the extent to which these problems may go undetected because of the salience of the EB problems. Estimates of the prevalence of language problems in samples of children with EB concerns range widely, from 30 to 70 percent. The current study seeks to extend this literature by examining the prevalence of language and literacy problems in a sample of children and adolescents enrolled in residential treatment program designed to ameliorate EB disorders. The study of this particular sample, one neither school- or hospital-based but at high risk for incarceration, is a novel contribution. Additionally, we will gather comprehensive information on the children's language strengths and weaknesses and relate the resulting profiles to their EB concerns. The detailed description of their language skills at the sound-, word-, sentence- and pragmatic levels in both spoken and written modalities will make a novel contribution to the literature.

q4.value:
Phase 1 (language screening) 
H1: The prevalence of language deficits (scoring below pre-determined cut points on a language screener, i.e., subtests of a standardized language assessment) in children and adolescents in an EB residential program will be higher than expected in the general (non EB) population (directional). 
H2: We hypothesize that the saliency of EB problems (especially the threat of harm that accompanies these problems) leads to under-identification of associated language concerns. Therefore, we predict that not all children who fail the language screening will have an existing special educational classification (IEP) with speech-language goals (directional). 
H3: Exploratory. We will determine whether scores and pass/fail rates vary by modality (written vs spoken), and biological sex. 
Phase 2 (language profiles) 
H4: Performance on the standardized language, reading, and pragmatic assessments will vary with EB problem severity, nonverbal IQ, socio-economic status (SES), biological sex, length of time in the residence program, and ADHD symptomology (directional). Children with greater EB severity, lower nonverbal IQ, lower SES, and higher ADHD symptomology will perform more poorly on language, reading, and pragmatic measures. Females will have a slightly higher performance. If the residence program is therapeutic, longer stay will be associated with higher performance. 
H5: Exploratory. We will determine whether language, reading, and pragmatic performance vary with presence of specific EB diagnosis, presence of history of substance use, callous and unemotional traits score, anxiety symptoms score, social anxiety symptoms score, depressive symptoms score, aggressive behavior score, substance use score, post traumatic stress disorder symptoms score. 
H6: Exploratory. We will construct profiles based on language scores on different subcomponents (modality = spoken and written; and domain = sounds/words, sentences/discourse) to determine whether certain modalities or domains are weaker than others.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Personnel who collect language data from subjects will not be aware of background information that may predict language scores including EB diagnosis/severity, SES, nonverbal IQ, or length in residence.

question.value:
This is a cohort study. In phase 1 (screening) we will estimate the prevalence of potential language deficits among children in a residential program for EB problems:
•	What percentage of all students screened fail the screener?
•	How does this compare to the expected failure rate in the general population?
We will determine the rate of special education service receipt (presence of an individualized education program with speech-language goals (IEP) - 2 levels) among those who fail the language screening. 
•	What percentage of children who fail the screener have an IEP for speech-language services?
We will explore patterns of ability in written language and spoken language (modality, 2 levels) by biological sex (2 levels) and age (continuous variable). 
•	Do children who fail have lower, higher, or equivalent scores in written vs spoken language?
•	Do boys fail at lower, higher, or equivalent rates than girls?
•	Are scores associated with age?
In phase 2 (profiles), we ask whether children who failed the language screening have a given profile of language deficits and whether that profile relates to demographics and emotional-behavioral health. 
•	Does the overall score on the TILLS correlate with EB function scores, nonverbal IQ, SES, length of time in residence, and ADHD symptoms score? (prediction: yes)
•	Do boys have lower, higher, or equivalent TILLS scores than girls? (prediction: lower)
•	Does the overall score on the CAPS correlate with EB function scores, nonverbal IQ, SES, length of time in residence, and ADHD symptoms score? (prediction: yes)
•	Do boys have lower, higher, or equivalent CAPS scores than girls? (prediction; lower)
•	Does reading lexiles correlate with EB function scores, nonverbal IQ, SES, length of time in residence, and ADHD symptoms score? (prediction: yes)
•	Do boys have lower, higher, or equivalent reading lexiles than girls? (prediction: lower)
We will explore other potential links between language performance and EB health.
•	Do overall scores on the TILLS, CAPS, and reading lexiles vary with
Categorical variables:
1) Presence of specific EB diagnoses - trauma, anxiety disorders, depression, attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder, conduct disorder/oppositional defiant disorder, substance abuse – 6 levels but more than one is possible
2) Presence of history of substance use - 2 levels 
Continuous predictors: 
1) Callous and unemotional traits score 
2) Anxiety symptoms score 
3) Social anxiety symptoms score 
4) Depressive symptoms score 
5) Aggressive behavior score 
8) Substance use score 
9) Post traumatic stress disorder symptoms score 
The TILLS scores can be combined to determine profiles of strengths and weaknesses by crossing scores for sounds/words and sentences/discourse with the modalities of speaking and writing. 
•	Do TILLS profiles vary such that scores on the sounds/words subtests are lower, higher, or equivalent to scores on the sentences/discourse subtests? 
•	Do TILLS profiles vary such that scores on the spoken subtests are lower, higher, or equivalent to scores on the written subtests?

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: Pre-existing data on this sample have been obtained as part of intake and/or as part of another observational study at the residence program include age, biological sex, race/ethnicity, SES, IEP classification, academic performance, reading lexile scores, nonverbal IQ, EB diagnosis, callous and emotional traits, anxiety symptoms, social anxiety symptoms, depressive symptoms, aggressive behavior, substance use history, post-traumatic stress disorder history, trauma history, and length of time at the residence program. The investigators of the current study have not yet had access to or observed these data and will not access the data prior to study registration.

question.value:
The population includes children and adolescents (ages 10 to 18) who are residents at Boys Town school, a residential program for children with behavioral concerns. Initial data exist on this population as a function of their residence in the program. Additional data exist for a subsample of children who have participated in a separate study of emotional-behavioral health. 
Additional data collection for this study will occur in two phases: In phase 1, we will conduct language screening on all residents of the program (a sample size of approximately 400). As this screening is an educational priority for the school's special education director, passive consent will be used for Phase 1. Additionally, payment will not be offered for this stage of the study. However, individuals will receive a prize for participation. Testing will last approximately 30 minutes per participant. Data collection for Phase 1 is expected to take approximately 1 year. 
Subsequently, in phase 2, 50 children/adolescents will be invited to participate in the second stage of the study involving full language testing. Because we are interested in the relation between language profiles and EB concerns of children with language problems, inclusion criteria include: a) failing the language screening, and b) having participated in the separate study, with existing data on emotional-behavioral health. This sample will be randomly selected from the residents who meet inclusion criteria. Full consent/assent is required from both parents/guardians and participants. Children/adolescents will be paid $15 per hour of participation (rounded up to the nearest half-hour). Testing will require two separate 90-minute visits. Data collection for Phase 2 is expected to last for approximately 2 years.

q13.value: Initial language screening (phase 1) will involve all residents at Boys Town: approximately 400. Phase 2 will include 50 children/adolescents.

q14.value: Phase 1 involves all eligible residents. Phase 2 sample size will be 50, which is in line with prior similar studies and also reflects feasibility for in-depth language testing given our current time and personnel constraints. This sample size gives us reasonable power to detect the main effects of interest. Assuming and equal number of boys and girls, we would have 80% power to reject the null hypothesis of equal TILL scores with a large effect size of 0.8 using a two-sample t-test at alpha=.05. We achieve 80% power to detect a difference in TILL scores between oral and written modalities with a medium effect size of 0.4 using a paired t-test at alpha=.05.

q15.value: We will stop data collection in Phase 1 when we reach 400 participants or one full year of data collection, whichever comes first.

question.value:
Phase 1: The outcome is measured as continuous standard scores on four subtests of the Test of Integrated Language and Literacy Skills (TILLS) and the binary pass/fail classification based on those scores ("Fail" = <5th percentile on any one subtest; <10th percentile on two or more subtests; <15th percentile on three or more subtests). The independent variables are age, biological sex, and status of special education receipt for speech/language disorder. 
Phase 2: The outcome is measured as continuous scores on the complete TILLS (standard score), the Clinical Assessment of Pragmatics (CAPs) (standard score), and Reading lexiles. 
Categorical predictors are 1) Presence of an emotional-behavioral (EB) diagnosis - 2 levels 1a) Presence of specific EB diagnoses - trauma, anxiety disorders, depression, attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder, conduct disorder/oppositional defiant disorder, substance abuse 2) Presence of history of substance use - 2 levels 3) Presence of an individualized education program (IEP) - 2 levels 3a) Nature of IEP (special education) - 13 potential categories 4) Biological sex - 2 levels 5) Race/ethnicity - 6 levels 
Continuous predictors including: 1) Callous and unemotional traits score 2) Anxiety symptoms score 3) Social anxiety symptoms score 4) Depressive symptoms score 5) Aggressive behavior score 6) ADHD symptoms score 7) Emotional and behavioral functioning 8) Substance use score 9) Post traumatic stress disorder symptoms score 10) Age 11) SES 12) Nonverbal IQ 13) Length of time in the residence program

Phase 1
H1: The prevalence of language deficits (“Fail” on the standardized language assessment) in children and adolescents in an EB residential program will be higher than expected in the general (non EB) population.
•	What percentage of all students screened fail the screener? Analysis = descriptive
•	How does this compare to the expected failure rate in the general population (7.58% given data in Norbury et al., 2016) Analysis = binomial proportion test.
H2: Not all children who fail the language screening will have an existing special educational classification (IEP) with speech-language goals.
•	What percentage of children who fail the screener have an IEP for speech-language services? Analysis = descriptive
H3: We will explore patterns of ability in written language and spoken language (modality, 2 levels) by biological sex (2 levels) and age (continuous variable). 
•	Do children who fail the screener have lower, higher, or equivalent scores in written vs spoken language? 
•	Do boys fail at lower, higher, or equivalent rates than girls? 
•	Does age correlate with continuous scores? 
Analysis = a random intercept linear mixed effects regression model with TILLS score as the dependent variable and modality, sex, and age as predictors. 
Phase 2
H4: We will measure language with three tools: TILLS, CAPs and reading lexiles. Children with greater EB severity, lower nonverbal IQ, lower SES, and higher ADHD symptomology will perform more poorly on all language measures. Females will have a slightly higher performance. If the residence program is therapeutic, longer stay will be associated with higher performance. 
•	Does the overall score on the TILLS vary with EB function scores, nonverbal IQ, SES, length of time in residence, and ADHD symptoms score? (prediction: yes)
•	Do boys have lower, higher, or equivalent TILLS scores than girls? (prediction: lower)
•	Does the overall score on the CAPS correlate with EB function scores, nonverbal IQ, SES, length of time in residence, and ADHD symptoms score? (prediction: yes)
•	Do boys have lower, higher, or equivalent CAPS scores than girls? (prediction; lower)
•	Does reading lexiles correlate with EB function scores, nonverbal IQ, SES, length of time in residence, and ADHD symptoms score? (prediction: yes)
•	Do boys have lower, higher, or equivalent reading lexiles than girls? (prediction: lower)
Analysis = We will conduct three multiple regression analyses, one each for TILLS, CAPs, and reading lexile scores as the dependent variable. For each, we will include EB function scores, nonverbal IQ, SES, length of time in residence, and ADHD symptom scores as continuous predictions and sex as a categorical predictor. Race/ethnicity will be a covariate. Age will also be included as a covariate for the reading lexiles analysis.
H5: Exploratory. Do overall scores on the TILLS, CAPS, and reading lexiles vary with:
•	Categorical variables:
•	1) Presence of specific EB diagnoses - trauma, anxiety disorders, depression, attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder, conduct disorder/oppositional defiant disorder, substance abuse – 6 levels but more than one is possible
•	2) Presence of history of substance use - 2 levels 
•	Continuous predictors: 
•	1) Callous and unemotional traits score 
•	2) Anxiety symptoms score 
•	3) Social anxiety symptoms score 
•	4) Depressive symptoms score 
•	5) Aggressive behavior score 
•	8) Substance use score 
•	9) Post traumatic stress disorder symptoms score 
Analysis = We will conduct three multiple regression analyses, one each for the TILLS, CAPs, and reading lexile scores as dependent variables. Each will include the above listed variables as predictors. Note: some of these variables might be highly correlated. The level of multicollinearity will be assessed using the Variance Inflation Factor. If multicollinearity is determined to be a major concern, we will use principal components analysis to combine correlated variables together. Possible covariates are age, sex, SES, nonverbal IQ, race/ethnicity, and length of time in the program. (Note: we will leave out any covariate that was not statistically or clinically significant in the analysis for H4)
H6: Exploratory. We will construct profiles based on language scores on different subcomponents (modality and domain), reading lexiles, and pragmatics to determine how language scores and profiles vary with demographics and EB measures.
The TILLS scores can be combined to determine profiles of strengths and weaknesses by crossing scores for sounds/words and sentences/discourse with the modalities of speaking and writing. 
•	Do TILLS profiles vary such that scores on the sounds/words subtests are lower, higher, or equivalent to scores on the sentences/discourse subtests? 
•	Do TILLS profiles vary such that scores on the spoken subtests are lower, higher, or equivalent to scores on the written subtests? 
Analysis: TILLS quadrant profiles will be based on significant score distinctions (i.e., no overlapping confidence intervals) for oral vs written composites and snd/wd vs sent/discourse composites. We will use a binomial test of proportions to determine whether a greater proportion of children present with a given profile vs another.

q20.value: The dependent variables of interest are standard scores. Therefore, they are defined to be normally distributed and there should be no need for transformations. However we will ly do transformations as needed if the data are not normally distributed. Categorical variables will be dummy coded.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining statistical significance of effects in the multiple regression models and binomial proportion tests. We will report standardized estimates, effect sizes, and p-values.

q23.value: Subjects with missing data on a dependent or predictor variable will be excluded from that particular analysis. Participants will not be excluded list-wise.

The impact of nonverbal ability on prevalence and clinical presentation of language disorder: evidence from a population study. Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry, 57(11), 1247-1257.

registration_responses.q1: Language and Literacy Problems among Children with Emotional-Behavioral Concerns
registration_responses.q2: Karla Kay McGregor, Erin Smolak, Jacob Oleson
registration_responses.q3:
The overall goal of the project is to determine the prevalence of language/literacy disorder among children with emotional-behavioral problems at Boys Town and to examine the association between their language profiles and their emotional-behavioral health.

Extant evidence suggests there is comorbidity of language/literacy disorders and emotional-behavioral (EB) concerns in children, adolescents, and adults. However, we know little about the nature of these language problems nor the extent to which these problems may go undetected because of the salience of the EB problems. Estimates of the prevalence of language problems in samples of children with EB concerns range widely, from 30 to 70 percent. The current study seeks to extend this literature by examining the prevalence of language and literacy problems in a sample of children and adolescents enrolled in residential treatment program designed to ameliorate EB disorders. The study of this particular sample, one neither school- or hospital-based but at high risk for incarceration, is a novel contribution. Additionally, we will gather comprehensive information on the children's language strengths and weaknesses and relate the resulting profiles to their EB concerns. The detailed description of their language skills at the sound-, word-, sentence- and pragmatic levels in both spoken and written modalities will make a novel contribution to the literature.
registration_responses.q4:
Phase 1 (language screening) 
H1: The prevalence of language deficits (scoring below pre-determined cut points on a language screener, i.e., subtests of a standardized language assessment) in children and adolescents in an EB residential program will be higher than expected in the general (non EB) population (directional). 
H2: We hypothesize that the saliency of EB problems (especially the threat of harm that accompanies these problems) leads to under-identification of associated language concerns. Therefore, we predict that not all children who fail the language screening will have an existing special educational classification (IEP) with speech-language goals (directional). 
H3: Exploratory. We will determine whether scores and pass/fail rates vary by modality (written vs spoken), and biological sex. 
Phase 2 (language profiles) 
H4: Performance on the standardized language, reading, and pragmatic assessments will vary with EB problem severity, nonverbal IQ, socio-economic status (SES), biological sex, length of time in the residence program, and ADHD symptomology (directional). Children with greater EB severity, lower nonverbal IQ, lower SES, and higher ADHD symptomology will perform more poorly on language, reading, and pragmatic measures. Females will have a slightly higher performance. If the residence program is therapeutic, longer stay will be associated with higher performance. 
H5: Exploratory. We will determine whether language, reading, and pragmatic performance vary with presence of specific EB diagnosis, presence of history of substance use, callous and unemotional traits score, anxiety symptoms score, social anxiety symptoms score, depressive symptoms score, aggressive behavior score, substance use score, post traumatic stress disorder symptoms score. 
H6: Exploratory. We will construct profiles based on language scores on different subcomponents (modality = spoken and written; and domain = sounds/words, sentences/discourse) to determine whether certain modalities or domains are weaker than others.

This is a cohort study. In phase 1 (screening) we will estimate the prevalence of potential language deficits among children in a residential program for EB problems:
•	What percentage of all students screened fail the screener?

We will determine the rate of special education service receipt (presence of an individualized education program with speech-language goals (IEP) - 2 levels) among those who fail the language screening.

Additional data collection for this study will occur in two phases: In phase 1, we will conduct language screening on all residents of the program (a sample size of approximately 400). Children/adolescents will be paid $15 per hour of participation (rounded up to the nearest half-hour). Testing will require two separate 90-minute visits. Data collection for Phase 2 is expected to last for approximately 2 years.

dependent.value:
Based on traits described above, which candidate do you think is more suitable for the governor position? 
A Maurice Johnson
B Qiming Zhao

conditions.value:
All participants will read about a scenario where a Black mayor (“Maurice Johnson”) and an Asian mayor (“Qiming Zhao”) are running for the position of a governor position. Both mayors are described to have made some accomplishments (adapted from websites of real mayors across partisan background) in their city, the content of which is counterbalanced. Critically, the position of governor is manipulated to be something that either requires traits that distinguish human from animal (Condition 1; “animal trait condition”) or requires traits that distinguish human from machine (Condition 2; “mechanical trait condition”). In other words, the position’s requirement in terms of what types of “human traits” are needed for it is manipulated across the two conditions. In the first condition, the position is said to require traits such as civility and moral sensibility and avoid traits such as irrationality and childlikeness. In the second condition, it is said to require traits such as emotional responsiveness and interpersonal warmth and avoid traits such as passivity and superficiality. 

The description of the positions is a figure that summarizes the key traits and the figure was modified from Figure 1 of the Halsam (2006) paper. The figure that participants see differ across the conditions. In the first condition, “Human uniqueness” in Haslam’s original graph is replaced with “Top traits required for the position,” and “Animalistic dehumanization” is replaced with “Top traits to be avoided for the position” in Condition 1, and likewise for “Human Nature” and “Mechanical dehumanization” in Condition 2.

hypothesis.value: It tests the hypothesis that a Black candidate is less likely than Asian candidate to be voted for a political office is described to require traits that distinguish human from animal, when compared with a position that requires traits that distinguish human from machine.

study_type_other.value:
Participants will be asked the following two questions for exploratory purpose 

Regardless your response above, how suitable do you think Maurice Johnson is for the position?
1=Not suitable at all. 7=extremely suitable

Regardless your response above, how suitable do you think Qiming Zhao is for the position?
1=Not suitable at all. 7=extremely suitable

In the first condition, “Human uniqueness” in Haslam’s original graph is replaced with “Top traits required for the position,” and “Animalistic dehumanization” is replaced with “Top traits to be avoided for the position” in Condition 1, and likewise for “Human Nature” and “Mechanical dehumanization” in Condition 2.

attributes.title: Why does aid not target the poorest?

q1.value: Why does aid not target the poorest?

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Prior work has demonstrated that aid, including World Bank aid, typically does not target poorer places within countries. It is not known why this is the case. I will evaluate a range of possible factors influencing subnational aid allocation, including: local politics, TTL career incentives, and aid effectiveness concerns.

q16.value: I will test a large number of hypotheses that are more fully described in the attached pre-registration plan. One of the more important hypotheses is that TTLs think that it is harder to implement projects in more rural or remote areas.

q17.value: Conjoint survey experiment on World Bank TTLs

q19.value: The survey is being sent to 2478 algorithmically-generated email addresses. Typical response rates on this population range from 5-15%.
